Knowledge Point: The transitive verb \japhug{sɯxɕe}{send}, `let go' is the causative of \japhug{ɕe}{go}, and its stem II presents an irregular vowel merger \forme{sɯɣ+ari} \rightarrow \forme{sɤɣri}, instead of expected \dagger\forme{sɤri} or \dagger\forme{asɯɣri} (§\ref{sec:caus.sAG}). Other derivations from \japhug{ɕe}{go} also have suppletion, but the alternations are regular. The autive and the vertitive \forme{nɯ-} prefixes (§\ref{sec:autobenefactive} , §\ref{sec:vertitive}) in \forme{nɯ-ɕe} `go by oneself'/`go back' are predictably infixed (§\ref{sec:inner.prefixal.chain}) within the stem II \forme{ari} as \forme{a<nɯ>ri} (see examples \ref{ex:Wrte.YAnWBde2} in §\ref{sec:autoben.lexicalized} and \ref{ex:tWZo.kW} in §\ref{sec:genr.pro}). the distributed action derivation \japhug{nɤɕɯɕe}{go around} likewise has the expected reduplicated stem \forme{-anɤrɯri}.
Content 1: \gll jɤ-a<nɯ>ri ri, ɯ-rte ɲɤ-nɯβde | \gls AOR-<VERT>go[II] LNK 3SG.POSS-hat IFR-lose | \glt `He went away, but lost his hat.'
Content 2: \gll tɯʑo kɯ tɯ-χti ɲɯ́-wɣ-nɯ-ɕar kɯ-maʁ kɯ, tɯ-pʰama ra kɯ tɯ-χti ɲɯ-ɕar-nɯ | \gls GENR ERG GENR.POSS-spouse IPFV-INV-AUTO-search INF:STAT-not.be ERG GENR.POSS-parent PL ERG GENR.POSS-spouse IPFV-search-PL | \glt `One could not choose one's spouse, one's parents chose one's spouse.'

Knowledge Point: The regular stem III \forme{βze} of the verb \japhug{βzu}{make} does appear in some non-finite forms such as \forme{cʰɯ-kɯ-βze} in (\ref{ex:Wmat.chWkWBze}) (see also \ref{ex:YWkWnWBze} in §\ref{sec:autoben.spontaneous}), in the dummy transitive subject construction (§\ref{sec:transitive.dummy}), meaning `grow' or in collocation with the noun \forme{ɯ-tsa} (in the meaning `be suitable', §\ref{sec:Bzu.lv}) for instance.
Content 1: \gll <hulu> nɯ si ci ɲɯ-ŋu, ɯ-mat cʰɯ-kɯ-βze ci. tɕe ɯ-mat nɯnɯ, ɯ-taʁ ku-kɯ-xtsʰɯm, ɯ-pa ɲɯ-kɯ-jpum ci cʰɯ-βze ɲɯ-ŋu tɕe, nɯ <hulu> tu-sɤrmi-nɯ. | \gls gourd DEM tree INDEF SENS-be 3SG.POSS-fruit IPFV-SBJ:PCP-make[III] INDEF LNK 3SG.POSS-fruit DEM 3SG.POSS-top IPFV:EAST-SBJ:PCP-be.thin 3SG.POSS-bottom IPFV:WEST-SBJ:PCP-be.thick INDEF IPFV-make[III] SENS-be LNK DEM gourd IPFV-call-PL | \glt `The gourd is a tree, one which grows fruits. It grows fruits that are thinner on the top part and thicker in the bottom, they are called `gourd'.'
Content 2: \gll tɕe zrɯɣ nɯ tɕe, tsuku kɯ tɯ-pɤcʰaʁ ɯ-ŋgɯ tu-nɯ-ɬoʁ ŋu tu-ti-nɯ ŋu tɕe mɤ-xsi ma ɯʑo ɲɯ-kɯ-nɯ-βze ci ɲɯ-ɕti tɕe, | \gls LNK louse DEM LNK some ERG INDEF.POSS-navel 3SG-inside IPFV-AUTO-come.out be:FACT IPFV-say-PL be:FACT LNK NEG-GENR:A:know LNK 3SG IPFV-SBJ:PCP-AUTO-grow INDEF SENS-be.AFF LNK | \glt `The louse, some say that it comes from the navel, I don't know, it grows by itself.'

Knowledge Point: Rather than an exception to the rules described in §\ref{sec:stem3.distribution}, it is simpler to consider that a synchronic verb root \japhug{βze}{grow} different from \japhug{βzu}{make} has been created by backformation (§\ref{sec:stem3.backformation}) from finite imperfective forms such as \forme{cʰɯ-βze} `it grows' in (\ref{ex:Wmat.chWkWBze}). The stem \forme{βze} however never occurs in past tenses (Inferential and Aorist), so that this verb is an example of partial and ongoing backformation.
Content 1: \gll <hulu> nɯ si ci ɲɯ-ŋu, ɯ-mat cʰɯ-kɯ-βze ci. tɕe ɯ-mat nɯnɯ, ɯ-taʁ ku-kɯ-xtsʰɯm, ɯ-pa ɲɯ-kɯ-jpum ci cʰɯ-βze ɲɯ-ŋu tɕe, nɯ <hulu> tu-sɤrmi-nɯ. | \gls gourd DEM tree INDEF SENS-be 3SG.POSS-fruit IPFV-SBJ:PCP-make[III] INDEF LNK 3SG.POSS-fruit DEM 3SG.POSS-top IPFV:EAST-SBJ:PCP-be.thin 3SG.POSS-bottom IPFV:WEST-SBJ:PCP-be.thick INDEF IPFV-make[III] SENS-be LNK DEM gourd IPFV-call-PL | \glt `The gourd is a tree, one which grows fruits. It grows fruits that are thinner on the top part and thicker in the bottom, they are called `gourd'.'

Knowledge Point: Three verbs presented in \tabref{tab:frozen.t} have two alternative stem forms in free variation, with an optional \forme{-t} suffix. This suffix appears in all person and TAME forms without any semantic change; compare for instance the Imperfective \textsc{1pl} forms \forme{ku-rɤʑit-i} (\textsc{ipfv}-stay-\textsc{1pl}, example \ref{ex:jisAxCe.maNe}, §\ref{sec:other.oblique.participle.relatives}) and \forme{ku-rɤʑi-j} (\textsc{ipfv}-stay-\textsc{1pl}, example \ref{ex:iZo.kWBde}, §\ref{sec:uses.numerals}), uttered by the same speaker. The two variants are freely interchangeable, but some speakers use the \forme{-t} suffixed forms more frequently that others.
Content 1: \gll iʑora tɕe kʰa ɯ-ŋgɯ kɤ-kɤ-ja ʑo ɲɯ-fse-j ku-rɤʑit-i ma [ji-sɤx-ɕe] maŋe | \gls 1PL LNK house 3SG.POSS-inside AOR-OBJ:PCP-close EMPH SENS-be.like-1PL IPFV-stay-1PL LNK 1PL.POSS-OBL:PCP-go not.exist:SENS | \glt `It was like we were locked in the house, with nowhere to go.'
Content 2: \gll tɕe iʑo kɯβde nɯ tɯtɯrca ku-rɤʑi-j tɕe, | \gls LNK 1PL four DEM together IPFV-stay-1PL LNK | \glt `The four of us were living together.'

Knowledge Point: In Factual Non-Past unprefixed verb forms, the \forme{a-} element surfaces without alternation, as in (§\ref{ex:aroa.me}).
Content 1: \gll nɯ ma aro-a me qʰe, | \gls DEM apart.from possess:FACT-1SG not.exist:FACT LNK | \glt `I don't have anything else.'

Knowledge Point: The prefixes in slots -6, -5 and -4 can occur in direct contact with the contracting vowel \forme{a-} only in Factual Non-Past non-second person forms (§\ref{sec:fact.morphology}). The vowel of Rhetorical Interrogative \forme{ɯβrɤ\trt}, Proximative aspect \forme{jɯ-} (-6) negative \forme{mɤ-} (-5) and associated motion prefixes \forme{ɕɯ-} and \forme{ɣɯ-} (-4) merge as \forme{a-}: \forme{ɯβrɤ-a-} \rightarrow \ipa{ɯβra\trt}, \forme{jɯ-a-} \rightarrow \ipa{ja\trt}, \forme{mɤ-a-} \rightarrow \ipa{ma\trt}, \forme{ɕɯ-a-} \rightarrow \ipa{ɕa-} and \forme{ɣɯ-a-} \rightarrow \ipa{ɣa\trt}, as shown in \forme{ɕɯ-anbaʁ-i} `we go and hide' \ipa{ɕanbaʁi} in (\ref{ex:CanbaRi}), \forme{mɤ-a-rɤt} `it has not yet been written' \ipa{marɤt} (example \ref{ex:marAt}, §\ref{sec:passive.stative}).
Content 1: \gll rŋgɯ ɯ-ŋgɯ nɯtɕu ɕɯ-anbaʁ-i ɯmɤ-kɯ-ntsʰi-ci ma, | \gls boulder 3SG.POSS-in DEM:LOC TRAL-hide:FACT-1PL PROB-PEG-be.better-PEG LNK | \glt `It looks like we should go and hide in the [hollow] boulder.'
Content 2: \gll jaʁmɤzdoʁzdoʁ nɯ kɯnɤ pɣa ŋu, mɤ-a-rɤt | \gls bird.sp. DEM also bird be:FACT NEG-PASS-write:FACT | \glt `The \forme{jaʁmɤzdoʁzdoʁ} is also a bird, it is not written (in the list of bird's names that had been prepared beforehand to ask about all known bird species).'

Knowledge Point: The interrogative \forme{ɯ-} in slot -6 does not merge with \forme{a-}. Rather, an epenthetic \forme{-j-} consonant is inserted between the two, as in (\ref{ex:WjatsWtsu}) with the verb \japhug{atsɯtsu}{have time}.
Content 1: \gll a-wa tɯrju χsɯ-ŋka tu-ti-a ɯ-j-átsɯtsu | \gls 1SG.POSS-father word three-word IPFV-say-1SG QU-X-have.time:FACT | \glt `Father, do I have time to say three sentences?'

Knowledge Point: These rules are not purely phonological, since the outcome of the vowel fusion with type A preverbs depends on the TAME category. For instance, in the case of the contracting verb \japhug{atɤr}{fall}, the type A \textsc{downwards} \forme{pɯ-} preverbs merges as \ipa{pɤ-} in the Irrealis and Imperative (for example \forme{a-mɤ-pɯ-ɤtɤr} \ipa{amɤpɤtɤr} in \ref{ex:amApAtAr}) and as \ipa{pa-} in the Past Imperfective and Perfective (\forme{pɯ-atɤr} \ipa{patɤr} in \ref{ex:li.patAr}).
Content 1: \gll a-mɤ-pɯ-ɤtɤr kɤ-sɯso kɯ, | \gls IRR-NEG-PFV-fall INF-think ERG | \glt `In order to prevent [the child] from falling down...'
Content 2: \gll li pɯ-atɤr ɲɯ-ŋu | \gls again AOR-fall SENS-be | \glt `He fell down again.'

Knowledge Point: In slot -2, since contracting verbs are all intransitive, only the second person \forme{tɯ-} and the generic \forme{kɯ-} prefixes and the prefixal element \forme{k(ɯ)-} of the peg circumfix can occur before the contracting vowel \forme{a-}. The outcome of vowel contraction depends on the TAME category (§\ref{sec:intr.23}: \forme{tɯ-a-} \ipa{ta-} in Factual Non-Past (\forme{tɯ-atɤr} `you will fall') and Aorist (\forme{pɯ-tɯ-atɤr} `you fell down') and \forme{tɯ-ɤ-} \ipa{tɤ-} Imperfective (\forme{pjɯ-tɯ-ɤtɤr} `you fall down'), Sensory, Egophoric Present, Irrealis, Imperative and Prohibitive (\forme{ma-pɯ-tɯ-ɤtɤr} `don't fall down'). With the peg circumfix, which appears in the Inferential, the vowel fusion is always \forme{-k-ɤ-} (see example \ref{ex:mWYAkAtWGnWci}, §\ref{sec:peg.circumfix}).
Content 1: \gll ndʑi-ɣi ra, nɯni mɯ-ɲɤ-\rouge{k}-ɤtɯɣ-nɯ-\rouge{ci} | \gls 3DU.POSS-relative PL DEM:DU NEG-IFR-PEG-meet-PL-PEG | \glt `Their relatives did not meet them (again).'

Knowledge Point: Second, when the initial syllable of the word contains more than one morpheme, as in the case of the \forme{ɕ-} or \forme{ʑ-} allomorphs of the translocative prefix combined with an orientation preverb (§\ref{sec:translocative.morpho}), reduplication can disregard morpheme boundaries, resulting in a replication of the two morphemes: \forme{ɕ-kɤ-tsʰi-t-a} (\textsc{tral}-\textsc{aor}-drink-\textsc{pst}:\textsc{tr}-\textsc{1sg}) thus yields \forme{\rouge{ɕ-kɯ}\redp{}ɕ-kɤ-tsʰi-t-a} as in (\ref{ex:CkWCkAtshita}). \iai{Tshendzin} however also accepts reduplication of the first morpheme only, reduplicated with addition of \forme{-ɯ} (\forme{\rouge{ɕɯ}\redp{}ɕ-kɤ-tsʰi-t-a}).
Content 1: \gll cʰa ɕkɯ\redp{}ɕ-kɤ-tsʰi-t-a ʑo lu-βzi-a ŋu | \gls alcohol ITER\redp{}TRAL-AOR-drink-PST:TR-1SG EMPH IPFV-be.drunk-1SG be:FACT | \glt `Each time I go and drink alcohol I get drunk.'

Knowledge Point: Example (\ref{ex:CtWtAkWtshAt}) illustrates a third possible pattern, with reduplication of the orientation preverb \forme{ɕ-tɤ-kɯ-tsʰɤt} \Rightarrow \forme{ɕ-\rouge{tɯ}\redp{}tɤ-kɯ-tsʰɤt} without affecting the associated motion marker.
Content 1: \gll kɯki tɯrme kɯra ɕ-tɯ\redp{}tɤ-kɯ-tsʰɤt ʑo nɯ pjɤ́-wɣ-sat-nɯ. | \gls DEM.PROX person DEM:PL TRAL-TOTAL\redp{}AOR-SBJ:PCP-try EMPH DEM IFR-INV-kill-PL | \glt `All of these men who had went and tried [to discover the princesses'

Knowledge Point: There are three possibilities in Japhug to mark the verbs in the protasis of conditionals (§\ref{sec:real.conditional}): Irrealis (§\ref{sec:irrealis.conditional}), Interrogative \forme{ɯ-} (§\ref{sec:interrogative.W.function}) and initial reduplication. In the latter two cases, the verb is generally followed by the additive linker \forme{nɤ}, as in (\ref{ex:atCW.tWtWNu.nA}).
Content 1: \gll a-tɕɯ tɯ\redp{}tɯ-ŋu nɤ, pɯ-ta-sɯxɕɤt nɯ ci nɯ-ndɯn ra | \gls 1SG.POSS-son COND\redp{}2-be:FACT ADD AOR-1\fl{}2-teach DEM once IMP-read be.needed:FACT | \glt `If you are my son, recite [the mantra] that I have taught you.'

Knowledge Point: Conditional reduplication interacts with TAME categories. For instance, reduplicated Aorist can be used to refer to hypothetical future events as in (\ref{ex:tWtAtWtWt.nA}). Without the \forme{nɤ} linker, reduplicated Aorist can be interpreted as Iterative coincidence (§\ref{sec:iterative.coincidence}).
Content 1: \gll tɯ\redp{}tɤ-tɯ-tɯt nɤ tɕe pjɯ-ta-sat ŋu | \gls COND\redp{}AOR-2-say[II] ADD LNK IPFV-1\fl{}2-kill be:FACT | \glt `If you tell [people] about [it], I will kill you.'

Knowledge Point: The scope of the protasis can go beyond the clause containing the reduplicated verb. In (\ref{ex:tWxtsa.mWmApWpe}), the protasis contains two clauses, the first one headed by the verb \forme{mɯ\redp{}mɤ-pɯ-pe} with reduplicated conditional, and the second one with the verb \forme{tu-kɯ-ŋke} without conditional marking.
Content 1: \gll tɕeri tɯ-mɤpa kɯnɤ, tɯ-xtsa mɯ\redp{}mɤ-pɯ-pe cʰondɤre, tɤ-rʑaʁ kɯ-rɲɟi tu-kɯ-ŋke qʰe, tɯ-mɤpa ri cimbɤrom tu-rke ŋgrɤl. | \gls LNK GENR.POSS-sole also GENR.POSS-shoe COND\redp{}NEG-PST.IPFV-be.good COMIT INDEF.POSS-time SBJ:PCP-be.long IPFV-GENR:S/O-walk LNK GENR.POSS-sole LOC blister IPFV-put.in[III] be.usually.the.case:FACT | \glt `On the soles too, if one (wears) bad shoes and walks for a long time, one gets blisters on one's sole.'

Knowledge Point: One of the meaning of initial reduplication with verbs in Aorist form is iterative coincidence (\citealt[295--296]{jacques14linking}). In this biclausal construction, the first clause with the reduplicated verb expresses the repetition of an event `every time X' (§\ref{sec:iterative.coincidence.clause}), and the second clause (with a main verb in the Imperfective) the resulting situation, as in (\ref{ex:tWtAGe.Zo}).
Content 1: \gll [kɯki tɕʰemɤpɯ ki si ɯ-kɯ-pʰɯt tɯ-tɤ-ɣe ʑo], nɯnɯ rgɤnmɯ nɯ ɣɯ ɯ-si ɲɯ-pʰɯt, ɯ-tɯ-ci z-ɲɯ-re, | \gls DEM.PROX girl DEM.PROX wood 3SG.POSS-SBJ:PCP-cut ITER\redp{}AOR:UP-come[II] EMPH DEM old.woman DEM GEN 3SG.POSS-wood IPFV-cut 3SG.POSS-INDEF.POSS-water TRAL-IPFV:WEST-fetch[III] | \glt `Every time the girl came to cut firewood, she would cut firewood for the old woman and fetch water for her.'

Knowledge Point: Although the semantic relationship between the two clauses is more a matter of temporal relationship rather than strict causality (for instance in example \ref{ex:tWtAGe.Zo}), this construction is clearly a subcase of the reduplicated conditional (§\ref{sec:redp.protasis}).
Content 1: \gll [kɯki tɕʰemɤpɯ ki si ɯ-kɯ-pʰɯt tɯ-tɤ-ɣe ʑo], nɯnɯ rgɤnmɯ nɯ ɣɯ ɯ-si ɲɯ-pʰɯt, ɯ-tɯ-ci z-ɲɯ-re, | \gls DEM.PROX girl DEM.PROX wood 3SG.POSS-SBJ:PCP-cut ITER\redp{}AOR:UP-come[II] EMPH DEM old.woman DEM GEN 3SG.POSS-wood IPFV-cut 3SG.POSS-INDEF.POSS-water TRAL-IPFV:WEST-fetch[III] | \glt `Every time the girl came to cut firewood, she would cut firewood for the old woman and fetch water for her.'

Knowledge Point: Verb-initial reduplication with adjectival stative verbs can express a gradual increase of degree `become more and more X'. This function occurs with TAME categories which have an inchoative meaning when used with stative verbs: the Imperfective (§\ref{sec:ipfv.inchoative}) as in (\ref{ex:chWchWtsxot}) and (\ref{ex:chWchWmACindZi}), the Aorist (§\ref{sec:aor.inchoative}) and the Inferential (§\ref{sec:ifr.inchoative}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll ʑɯrɯʑɤri tɕe cʰɯ\redp{}cʰɯ-mɤɕi-ndʑi nɤ cʰɯ\redp{}cʰɯ-mɤɕi-ndʑi tɕe | \gls progressively LNK INCR\redp{}IPFV-be.rich-DU ADD INCR\redp{}IPFV-be.rich-DU LNK | \glt `They progressively became richer and richer.'

Knowledge Point: Verb-initial reduplication can be combined with verb repetition and the additive linker \forme{nɤ} to put emphasis on the steadiness of the increase, as in (\ref{ex:chWchWmACindZi}).
Content 1: \gll ʑɯrɯʑɤri tɕe cʰɯ\redp{}cʰɯ-mɤɕi-ndʑi nɤ cʰɯ\redp{}cʰɯ-mɤɕi-ndʑi tɕe | \gls progressively LNK INCR\redp{}IPFV-be.rich-DU ADD INCR\redp{}IPFV-be.rich-DU LNK | \glt `They progressively became richer and richer.'

Knowledge Point: The negation \forme{mɯ-} of the Imperfective, reduplicated as \forme{mɯ\redp{}mɤ\trt}, can express gradual decrease, as in (\ref{ex:tWtucha.mWmAYWcha}).
Content 1: \gll ɬɤndʐi nɯ rca, tɯ\redp{}tu-cʰa ʑo pjɤ-ɕti. tɕendɤre, ɯʑo nɯnɯ tɕe ʑɯrɯʑɤri tɕe, mɯ\redp{}mɤ-ɲɯ-cʰa ʑo pjɤ-ɕti tɕe | \gls demon DEM UNEXP:DEG INCR\redp{}IPFV-can EMPH IFR.IPFV-be.AFF LNK 3SG DEM LNK progressively LNK INCR\redp{}NEG-IPFV-can EMPH IFR.IPFV-be.AFF LNK | \glt `The demon was becoming stronger and stronger, and he was weaker and weaker.'

Knowledge Point: In the case of participial relatives, the reduplicated syllable is the first syllable of the verb other than the possessive prefix, either the subject participle prefix \forme{kɯ-} (\ref{ex:kWkWspoR.Zo}), the object participle \forme{kɤ-} (\ref{ex:kWkAsWso}) or an orientation preverb (\ref{ex:tWtAkWrWkhArlAn}).
Content 1: \gll laχtɕʰa ŋotɕu nɤ-kɤ-sɯso ʑo nɯnɯ, nɤ-mɲaʁ, nɤ-rna, nɤ-ɕna cʰo ra [kɯ\redp{}kɯ-spoʁ] nɯ ɯ-ŋgɯ tɕe a-kɤ-tɯ-rke qʰe | \gls thing where 2SG.POSS-OBJ:PCP-think EMPH DEM 2SG.POSS-eye 2SG.POSS-ear 2SG.POSS-nose COMIT PL TOTAL\redp{}SBJ:PCP-have.a.hole DEM 3SG.POSS-in LOC IRR-PFV:EAST-2-put.in[III] LNK | \glt `Whatever things you want (from the granary), put it in your eyes, your ears, your nose etc, all the holes in your body.'
Content 2: \gll wuma ʑo ɲɯ-pe ndɤre, [kɯ\redp{}kɤ-sɯso] nɯ ɲɯ-fse | \gls really EMPH SENS-be.good LNK TOTAL\redp{}OBJ:PCP-think DEM SENS-be.like | \glt `It is very nice, it is like everything that [I] want.'
Content 3: \gll tɕe ɯ-tʰɤcu prɤscʰɯ ra [tɯ\redp{}tɤ-kɯ-rɯkʰɤrlɤn] kɯ nɯ-rdɤstaʁ nɯ ntsɯ s-cʰɤ-nɯ-ru-nɯ tɕe to-nɯ-ntɕʰoz-nɯ. | \gls LNK 3SG.POSS-downstream TOPO PL TOTAL\redp{}AOR-SBJ:PCP-build.house ERG 3PL.POSS-stone DEM always TRAL-IFR:DOWNSTREAM-AUTO-fetch-PL LNK IFR-AUTO-use-PL | \glt `All people from Praskyu down there who built/repaired their houses went there and took stones to use for themselves.'

Knowledge Point: In finite relatives, the verb lacks any overt nominalization marker other than the reduplication itself. In this construction, the relativized elements are either direct objects (as in \ref{ex:pWpWfCata.nWra.kW} and \ref{ex:spWspe} below), semi-objects or goals, but never subjects (§\ref{sec:finite.relatives}).
Content 1: \gll ɯ-ro nɯra [iɕqʰa pɯ\redp{}pɯ-fɕat-a] nɯra kɯ tɕe tɕe sɯjno tu-ndza-nɯ | \gls 3SG.POSS-rest DEM:PL just.before TOTAL\redp{}AOR-tell-1SG DEM:PL ERG LNK LNK grass IPFV-eat-PL | \glt `The rest, all the [other animals] that I have told about just before eat grass.'
Content 2: \gll nɯ [spɯ\redp{}spe] nɯ to-nɤrmi ri tɤte <zhima> kɤ-ti nɯ ɲɤ-nɯ-jmɯt | \gls DEM TOTAL\redp{}be.able.to:FACT DEM IFR-call.name LNK that.is sesame INF-say DEM IFR-AUTO-forget | \glt `He called the names of all [the crops] he knew, but forgot to say `sesame'.'

Knowledge Point: Finite transitive verbs with totalitative reduplication and a \textsc{1sg} subject can optionally take plural indexation (§\ref{sec:indexation.mixed}) corresponding to the relativized direct object with universal quantification. Object plural indexation in this case is rare (it is absent for instance in \ref{ex:pWpWfCata.nWra.kW} above), and only one example is attested in the corpus: \forme{pɯ\redp{}pɯ-mto-t-a-nɯ} (\textsc{total}\redp{}\textsc{aor}-see-\textsc{pst}:\textsc{tr}-\textsc{1sg}-\textsc{pl}) `all those that I have seen' (\ref{ex:pWpWmtotanW}, §\ref{sec:double.number.indexation}).
Content 1: \gll ɯ-ro nɯra [iɕqʰa pɯ\redp{}pɯ-fɕat-a] nɯra kɯ tɕe tɕe sɯjno tu-ndza-nɯ | \gls 3SG.POSS-rest DEM:PL just.before TOTAL\redp{}AOR-tell-1SG DEM:PL ERG LNK LNK grass IPFV-eat-PL | \glt `The rest, all the [other animals] that I have told about just before eat grass.'
Content 2: \gll nɯnɯ [tɕʰeme pɯ\redp{}pɯ-mto-t-a-nɯ] ɯ-ŋgɯ nɯ kɯ-fse kɯ-mpɕɤr maŋe | \gls DEM girl TOTAL\redp{}AOR-see-PST:TR-1SG-PL 3SG.POSS-inside DEM SBJ:PCP-be.like SBJ:PCP-be.beautiful not.exist:SENS | \glt `This is the most beautiful among all the girls I have ever seen.'

Knowledge Point: Totalitative reduplication of transitive subject participle is only possible if no possessive prefix is present (see \ref{ex:tWrme.pWpWkWmto}, §\ref{sec:totalitative.relatives}).
Content 1: \gll [\textbf{tɯrme} [pɯ\redp{}pɯ-kɯ-mto]] kɯ ɲɯ-nɤ-mpɕɤr-nɯ tɕe ``ɲɯ-pe" tu-ti-nɯ pjɤ-ŋu | \gls person TOTAL\redp{}AOR-SBJ:PCP-see ERG SENS-TROP-be.beautiful-PL LNK SENS-be.good IPFV-say-PL IFR.IPFV-be | \glt `All the people who saw it found it beautiful and said it was nice.'

Knowledge Point: When occurring in word-initial position, the autive prefix \forme{nɯ-} can be reduplicated to express emphatic permansive `still X (regardless of whatever may happen)', and such verb form can be repeated with the additive linker \forme{nɤ}, as in (\ref{ex:nWnWtu}).
Content 1: \gll tɤtʰo nɯ pɯpɯŋunɤ, tɕe nɯ mɤ-fse tɕe tɕendɤre ɯ-jwaʁ nɯ nɯ\redp{}nɯ-tu nɤ nɯ\redp{}nɯ-tu qʰe | \gls pine DEM as.for LNK DEM NEG-be.like:FACT LNK LNK 3SG.POSS-leaf DEM EMPH\redp{}AUTO-exist:FACT ADD EMPH\redp{}AUTO-exist:FACT LNK | \glt `As for the pine, it is not like [the other trees], [whatever happens], its leaves (needles) are still there.'

Knowledge Point: The reduplicated autive should not be mistaken with the combination of a type A `westward' orientation preverb \forme{nɯ-} with the autive in spontaneous function (§\ref{sec:autoben.spontaneous}) as in (\ref{ex:nWnWme}).
Content 1: \gll ɯʑo nɯ-nɯ-me ɕti. | \gls 3SG AOR-AUTO-not.exist be.AFF:FACT | \glt `[The wart] disappeared by itself.'

Knowledge Point: With adjectival stative verbs, emphatic reduplication indicates a high degree, opposite of the attenuative reduplication (§\ref{sec:attenuative}): compare for instance \forme{qarŋɯ\redp{}rŋe} `be deep yellow' vs. \forme{aqarŋɯ\redp{}rŋe} `be yellowish'. Reduplicated adjectival verbs are almost always attested in participial form, as in (\ref{ex:kWmpCWmpCAr.kWpWpe}).
Content 1: \gll tɕʰeme kɯ-mpɕɯ\redp{}mpɕɤr kɯ-pɯ\redp{}pe ci nɤ-ɕɣa kɯ-xtɕɯ\redp{}xtɕi ci a-nɯ-tɯ-ɤβzu smɯlɤm | \gls girl SBJ:PCP-EMPH\redp{}be.beautiful SBJ:PCP-EMPH\redp{}be.good INDEF 2SG.POSS-tooth/age SBJ:PCP-EMPH\redp{}be.small INDEF IRR-PFV-2-become prayer | \glt `May you become a very beautiful, nice young girl.'

Knowledge Point: Rare examples of emphatic adjectival verbs in finite form are however also found in the corpus, in (\ref{ex:YWwGrWwGrum}).
Content 1: \gll ɯ-ku nɯra tɕe nɤki, ɯ-kɤχcɤl nɯra li ɲɯ-qarŋe qʰe ɲɯ-wɣrɯ\redp{}wɣrum kɯ-fse. | \gls 3SG.POSS-head DEM:PL LNK FILLER 3SG.POSS-top.head DEM:PL again SENS-be.yellow LNK SENS-EMPH\redp{}be.white SBJ:PCP-be.like | \glt `It is yellow and very white on the top of its head.'

Knowledge Point: With the negative existential verb \japhug{me}{not exist}, emphatic reduplication indicates radical non-existence `not (have/exist) ... at all', as in (\ref{ex:nAwa.pWnnWmWme}).\footnote{In (\ref{ex:nAwa.pWnnWmWme}), the mother of the character Padma 'Od'bar, who asked her about the identity of father, gives this answer in the hope that her son will not try to find the truth about the disappearance of his father and thereby run into a mortal danger. }
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Emphatic reduplication also occurs with modal verbs such as the semi-transitive \japhug{rga}{like} (\ref{ex:kWrgWrga.tWrme}) and the transitive \japhug{spa}{be able} (\ref{ex:kArWCmi.kWspWspa}) to express high degree.
Content 1: \gll kɯ-rgɯ\redp{}rga ʑo tɯrme ra maŋe-nɯ ma | \gls SBJ:PCP-EMPH\redp{}like EMPH people PL not.exist:SENS-PL LNK | \glt `There are no people who like it a lot.'

Knowledge Point: Often in combination with the autive \forme{nɯ-} (§\ref{sec:autoben.spontaneous}), emphatic reduplication occurs in free-choice correlatives and in universal concessive conditional constructions (§\ref{sec:universal.concessive.conditional}) as in (\ref{ex:tChi.lAwGnWjWji.Zo}), without any constraint of the verb category.\footnote{In (\ref{ex:tChi.lAwGnWjWji.Zo}), the subject of the verb \forme{pe} `(it) is good' is not the crop referred to by the interrogative pronoun \forme{tɕʰi}, but the planting activity. To analyze this example as a correlative, one would have to suppose that a complement clause such as \forme{nɯnɯ kɤ-ji} `planting that' has been elided before \forme{pe} (on \japhug{pe}{be good} as a com\-ple\-ment-taking verb, see example \ref{ex:kAji.mApe} (§\ref{sec:adjective.complement}). }
Content 1: \gll tɯ-ji sna tɕe, [tɕʰi lɤ́-wɣ-nɯ-jɯ\redp{}ji] ʑo pe | \gls INDEF.POSS-field be.good LNK what AOR-INV-AUTO-EMPH\redp{}plant EMPH be.good:FACT | \glt `(The type of earth called \forme{tɤtʂo}) is fit (to be used) as fields, whatever one plants in it, [the planting] will be good (successful).'
Content 2: \gll tɯ-ji sna tɕe, [tɕʰi lɤ́-wɣ-nɯ-jɯ\redp{}ji] ʑo pe | \gls INDEF.POSS-field be.good LNK what AOR-INV-AUTO-EMPH\redp{}plant EMPH be.good:FACT | \glt `(The type of earth called \forme{tɤtʂo}) is fit (to be used) as fields, whatever one plants in it, [the planting] will be good (successful).'
Content 3: \gll tɤtʂo ɯ-ŋgɯ nɯtɕu [staχpɯ kɤ-ji] mɤ-pe | \gls earth.type 3SG.POSS-in DEM:LOC pea INF-plant NEG-be.good:FACT | \glt `Planting peas in \forme{tɤtʂo}-type earth is not good.'

Knowledge Point: Although emphatic reduplication is highly productive and regular, a handful of verbs have irregular reduplication patterns. The transitive verb \japhug{rɤtɕaʁ}{tread on} has the emphatic form \japhug{rɤtɕɯmtɕaʁ}{trample} (compare example \ref{ex:kWNGio.YWsaRdAt}, §\ref{sec:proprietive.generic} with \ref{ex:amAtAndonW.ma.GWznAndAGnW}, §\ref{sec:genr.3pl}) with \forme{-ɯm} reduplicated syllable (§\ref{sec.distributed.action.oR}). The stative verb \japhug{mdi}{be complete} has the emphatic form \forme{mdoʁmdi} with \forme{-oʁ} reduplication (§\ref{sec.distributed.action.oR}), and \japhug{tsʰu}{be fat} has the suffixed \forme{-e} reduplicated form \japhug{tsʰutsʰe}{be very fat}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll tɕe sɤndɤɣ tu-ti-nɯ ŋgrɤl. tɕe a-pɯ-sɯχsɤl-nɯ ʁo tɕe maka mɤ-pʰɯt-nɯ, na-pʰɯt-nɯ kɯnɤ cʰɯ-βde-nɯ ɕti. tɕe pjɯ-rɤtɕɯmtɕaʁ-nɯ ma `tɯrme ra kɯ a-mɤ-tɤ-ndo-nɯ ma ɣɯ-z-nɤndɤɣ-nɯ' ɲɯ-sɯso-nɯ. | \gls LNK be.poisonous:FACT IPFV-say-PL be.usually.the.case:FACT LNK IRR-PFV-recognize-PL ADVERS LNK at.all NEG-take.out:FACT-PL AOR:3\fl{}3'-take.out-PL even IPFV-throw.away-PL be.AFF:FACT LNK AOR-tread-PL LNK people PL ERG IRR-NEG-PFV-take-PL LNK INV-CAUS-be.poisoned:FACT-PL SENS-think-PL | \glt `People say that [this species of mushroom] is poisonous. If they recognize it, they don't pick it up, even if they pick it up they throw it away and stamp on it, thinking `[This way] other people won't take it and it will not poison them.''

Knowledge Point: The verb \japhug{fse}{be like} has the irregular reduplicated form \forme{-fsɤ\redp{}fse} alonside \forme{-fsɯ\redp{}fse} in universal concessive conditionals (\forme{tɕʰi pɯ-nɯ-fsɤ\redp{}fse}`in any case', example \ref{ex:tChi.pWnWfsAfse.Zo}, §\ref{sec:universal.concessive.conditional}).
Content 1: \gll [tɕʰi pɯ-nɯ-fsɤ\redp{}fse] ʑo nɤ-rca tu-kɯ-tsɯm-a ra | \gls what PST.IPFV-AUTO-EMPH\redp{}be.like EMPH 2SG.POSS-together IPFV-2\fl{}1-take.away-1SG be.needed:FACT | \glt `In any case (whatever the circumstances are like), take me with you.'
